short: If you concede something, you admit that it is true, proper, or certain ŌĆö usually in an unwilling way and often in the context of a competition, as in "At midnight, the candidate finally conceded defeat."
long: In its most common senses, a near synonym of concede is acknowledge ŌĆö if your mom is pointing out that you need sleep before the test, you should concede the truth of what she's saying. But another meaning of concede is to give away or grant something, as when an unpopular leader is unwilling to concede power. Concede is from Latin conc─ōdere, from the prefix com-, "completely," plus c─ōdere, "to go along, grant, yield." The corresponding noun is concession.
